tweets.text: I’ll start with, say, 25 opinions about nomadism. Then 1 per like if anyone’s interested. https://t.co/5vUnUONLCu
1. you can’t ever go home again. the place is still there, but it will never be what you thought it was before.

2. How many moves it takes to become a nomad depends a lot on your support structures and how you use them. Moving across the world with a plan to move back to your hometown eventually? You’ll probably just think the new place is cool and weird and different.

3. being a nomad gave  me the opportunity to see from the outside and reveal some things I already knew under the surface. In the USA I saw how things were somewhat differently fucked up in every city/state but it took getting away to see the deep roots the issues shared.

4. if you’re going this route, figure out what your minimal support system looks like and set it up ASAP. If you don’t acknowledge that you have emotional/social needs, you won’t figure out how to meet them until you finally have to confront and diagnose your discomfort.

5. If your travel style is asocial, then you’ll eventually get bored of traveling. Why go somewhere for just a change of scenery? If you hear a rowdy crew of English brothers in their sixties, buy a round and listen to some stories!

6. After spending a month back in the US, what  struck me was the wasted possibilities. I felt a pull to have space again - a workshop - but I had to remind myself that it’s not the space, or the tools that bring results. Figure out what is your core and bring only that with you.
(I just realized that most of this is going to be deeply personal advice to myself.)

7. I’m white. I have an MBA. I get called an “expat” instead of an “economic migrant”. I get special or unique treatment everywhere I go. Sometimes that’s OK, or embarrassing, and sometimes it makes me a mark. But I always try to keep in mind how it affects the people around me.
8. you have no idea how many wrong assumptions and stereotypes you have about every. single. country. thanks tv and film industries.

9. Europe and the USA better figure out how to get things done if we want to stay competitive in the next century. American infrastructure is crumbling next to Holland, and Holland seems... limited compared to cities in Asia.
